I don't have the proper locals for doing experiments involving manganese, but I'm curious. It is a strong oxidizer, but when it splashes out onto the wooden board, it seems to do little more than blacken the wood.
If instead of introducing the fuel into an excess of the oxidizer, what would happen if you pour a small amount of the manganese heptoxide onto fuel sources (like wood, a phone book or similar)?
If you look at the simplest mil. incendiaries, like napalm, they are incredibly good at igniting things. The earliest types of napalm which were just a slurry of a gelling agent ("soap") and a good fuel. During the development of the less savoury "bat bomb", the researchers observed that a very small amount of the slurry dropped onto a 4" wood beam would reliably ignite the solid wood without tindering, and the wood would keep burning after the gasoline had burnt off.
Old school napalm has a very high energy density allowing it to ignite things which would otherwise need tinder in order to ignite. My question is if manganese heptoxide would have similar properties, or if its energy density is so low that it can only blacken the wood rather than ignite it.

Just a question about nomenclature. Do you have any idea what the deal is with manganese compounds? I mean, MnO2 should be Manganese (IV) oxide, but it is called manganese dioxide, and Mn2O7 should be Manganese (VII) oxide, but it is called manganese heptoxide. And even weirder, MnCl2 isn't called manganese dichloride like the patter wold suggest; it is actually called manganese (II) chloride!
What is up with that!!!????!?!?!?!?!?!?!??!?!?!?!?!?!!??!
